quote: I use AI mainly to make quick corrections and to rephrase sentences for sending administrative emails.
For rephrasing exchanges with a real estate agency, the AI helped me add precision to my sentences and adopt a slightly more formal and cordial style.
Using AI in a professional context — now we have a tool managed by the data team, but given the secure environment I work in, at the bank level, it was very complicated to use, for example, ChatGPT.

the most important thing a personal assistant can do is understand my request with very precise context, so that it can help me effectively while allowing me to make my personal adjustments as little as possible.

what would interest me is that it's directly connected, at least in my professional case, directly to our data and brings more precision. Because right now, it's me who gives it a lot of context with variables, and it isn't capable, at least for us, of retrieving those variables and therefore doing an analysis, for example.

I had already tried, but there was already an AI assistant that allowed job searching and to apply directly to multiple positions that interest me. So I think that would be an interesting feature to include as an extension, because searching for jobs or new positions can be very time-consuming.
Directly on software like Content Square, for example, and then it could also be made available directly on Google Meet, indeed, on Google Calendar and Mail.

On Google Calendar, it would allow detecting occurrences directly with other collaborators whose schedules I'm checking and give me the slots that are directly available, for example next week or the following two weeks.

On Google Meet, for example, it would allow me — although it already exists, but in our company it's impossible — to generate automatic meeting summaries, which takes a lot of time and would allow for more precision regarding the minutes.
there's less context, less opportunity to explain why I'm doing this interview and to ask other questions and to follow up a bit more.
often there are two questions in each question — well, each question contains two questions inside — and potentially fewer ways to follow up.
I'm a bit more lost in my answer, and I tend to ask myself: is this the right answer?
